title: How to End a Chess Game

steps.headline: Think six to seven moves ahead of the game, and always know what every single piece can do, every moment of the game.
steps.description: When people do not do this, they make stupid mistakes.

steps.headline: Protect enough pieces along with your king to last you through a simple endgame, which is between your king and some other pieces against your opponent's king.
steps.description: The extra pieces may be two bishops (hard), one rook (sort of hard), a queen (somewhat easy), or two rooks (very easy). A knight and a bishop checkmate, while possible, takes at least 30 moves by professionals.

steps.headline: Learn the simple endgames mentioned above, with the possible exception of the knight and bishop.
steps.description: Knowing how to do them quickly and easily will save you the frustration of figuring it out when put on the spot. EXPERT TIP																															Vitaly Neimer																International Chess Master								Vitaly Neimer is an International Chess Master and Certified Professional Chess Coach with over 15 years of training experience. He has been a part of the United States' Webster SPICE national chess champion team and is also a two-time Israeli national chess champion. Vitaly Neimer			International Chess Master				You can use tactics like Castling to the other side of the opponent. This is called Opposite Side Castling and it means the game is getting sharper. You are basically starting a pawn storm on your opponents’ side, so he then starts one on your side. It gets very bloody until someone mates first.

steps.headline: Move your king towards the center in the endgame.
steps.description: Checkmate is likely if your king is at the edges of the board and even more so in the corners.

steps.headline: Place your most powerful piece next to your king.
steps.description: This will prevent the piece from being taken by the enemy's king.

steps.headline: Make sure your own pieces are on squares of a color opposite of the square your opponent's bishop is on, if your opponent has only one.
Get your king next to pawns, preferably near your opponent's side of the board, so you can block checks by rooks and queens, which cost you moves, and protect your own pawns.
Use your king aggressively, especially if you don't have a queen.
steps.description: The king can be used to block your opponent's king from moving to certain squares.

steps.headline: Try to fork or pin enemy pieces in the endgame without losing any of your own pieces you need for checkmate.
steps.description: The less pieces your opponent has, the more simple the endgame will be.

steps.headline: Check your opponent's king constantly if you think you're opponent's trying to trick you into a stalemate.
steps.description: This is a great way to get rid of extra pieces that may interfere with your checkmating procedure.
